all_steps.name: Monaco
all_steps.description: View from our hotel balcony.

all_steps.name: More Trains!
all_steps.description: We had more train adventures today. Our route required 3 different trains and then a bus for 6 hours of travel. Learning from our previous mistakes, we left with plenty of time to spare. That train went well and we played games as we went. When we arrived our next train was at the station on the next platform waiting for us, but we didn’t see the ticket counter. So we hurried and bought tickets online. After we departed, they were checking tickets and it turned out we bought tickets for the wrong day. We were charged $50 each for having invalid tickets. But at least we were able to stay on the train. More lessons learned! We were able to ride the next train with zero hiccups, hooray! But we were definitely holding our breath when they came by to check our tickets. We decided to skip the bus and get a taxi. He tried to over charge us — ugh, we hate the black box of taxi charges. The roads were steep and windy, but we finally got to our house!

all_steps.name: Pitelli
all_steps.description:
We made it to Pitelli, Italy. Home for the next while. It will be really nice 1) being in a nice quiet town, close to mountains and the beach, and 2) being in one place for the next 10 days so we can settle a bit more. I am really tired right now. 

The town is really steep and hilly. It has a small grocery store, pizza shop, and park. We tested all three out!

all_steps.name: Baia Blu
all_steps.description: Today we went swimming in a beautiful blue bay! We got sunburnt, we don’t have Italian skin!

all_steps.name: Rainbow
all_steps.description: It was a rainy day so we hung out at home and got caught up on school work. But we did see the most gorgeous rainbow ever! It was so bright and vivid and complete.

all_steps.name: San Terenzo
all_steps.description: A gorgeous beach with the best sand and warm, calm water. The bay had an old castle on each side and the town was hilly with colorful houses. The kids practiced their engineering building a huge moat with castles. It drew in multiple kids that they became friends with. Harvey said it was the best beach he had ever been to! And we couldn’t get Fran to come home.

all_steps.name: Cinque Terre
all_steps.description:
Today we took a ferry boat tour to Cinque Terre. The Cinque Terre area is a popular tourist destination. Over the centuries, people have built terraces on the rugged, steep landscape right up to the cliffs that overlook the Ligurian Sea. Paths, trains, and boats connect the villages as cars can only reach them with great difficulty from the outside via narrow and precarious mountain roads.

The “five villages” are Monterosso al Mare, Vernazza, Corniglia, Manarola, and Riomaggiore. We stopped in Vernazza and Monterosso, and then the neighboring Portovenere.

This area is a UNESCO heritage site and not only iconic and picturesque, but full of history. The Disney movie Luca is set here.

It was way too busy and over crowded, but one day I’d still like to hike between towns. But in the off season!

all_steps.name: La Spezia Branch
all_steps.description: Today we attended the La Spezia branch in Italian for church. As we arrived, I was feeling tired and exhausted from the week, a bit homesick. But the prelude music was comforting and made me feel a little at home. What was especially neat was the pianist was blind!

all_steps.name: Gulf of Poets
all_steps.description:
The area we are in is called the gulf of poets, or Gorfo di Poêti. This areas beauty has attracted many artists. Among them: writers David Herbert Lawrence and Percy Bysshe Shelley and Mary Shelly, writer and painter George Sand, and poet Lord Byron.

Mediterranean
The sun,
The salt,
The sea.
Is the perfect recipe
For me!

	⁃	Harvey Chaney & Lisa Tobey

all_steps.name: San Terenzo Beach
all_steps.description: The kids love going to San Terenzo beach. The water is warm, clear and calm and the sand is perfect. They have made a lot of friends with their digging! Today they made an epic sand castle, it was an attraction for sure! Fran became friends with Sophie from Parma. And we loved playing with Francesco!

all_steps.name: Good bye Pitelli!
all_steps.description:
Today we are leaving our airbnb in Pitelli. This stop had many highs and lows. It was quiet and had great views. It was a beautiful area and we absolutely loved the view from our balcony of the gulf of poets a la spezia bay. The church bells were magical (although a little loud at 7am). Here we fell in love with swimming in the Mediterranean Sea. Blue Bay was stunning, cinque Terre was iconic, and San Terrenzo beach was the best we have ever been to. We went back and back to San Terenzo beach. The kids digging and building in the perfect sand were a magnet to other kids that wanted to play. Fran became friends with Sophie & her Nonna and Nono. Fransicco and his family were a delight to play with too. We built the most epic sand castle villages.

But, Pitelli was also hard. The small town on the hill had very few amenities. Even our airbnb felt like we were camping, having to ration through our limited supplies. In Pitelli we LOVED Red’s pizza and ate there frequently. We didn’t have a car (and were afraid to get one and drive and park on those crazy, narrow, windy, and steep streets). The bus was infrequent and unreliable. It was easier to walk. We got stronger — Pitelli calves — walking up the hill. But I think one of the hardest parts was how cold people in this region are towards tourists. There were some nice people. And we met some wonderful people at the beach (who were on holiday). But overall, people were cold and not very helpful or friendly. It was hard because I did so much research on the area, I thought it would be a perfect home base for a longer stay. It was really good to have a slower pace here, catch up on school and work.

all_steps.name: Tower of Pisa
all_steps.description:
Construction on the Tower of Pisa began in 1173 and took nearly 200 years to build due to war and other disruptions. Due to the soft ground and poor foundation, it almost immediately began to lean. 

By 1990, the tilt had reached 5.5 degrees. The structure was stabilized by remedial work between 1993 and 2001, which reduced the tilt to 3.97 degrees. 

The height of the tower is 55.86 metres (183 feet 3 inches) from the ground on the low side and 56.67 m (185 ft 11 in) on the high side. The width of the walls at the base is 2.44 m (8 ft 0 in). Its weight is estimated at 14,500 tonnes (16,000 short tons). The tower has 296 or 294 steps; the seventh floor has two fewer steps on the north-facing staircase.

Galileo Galilei, who lived in Pisa at the time, is said to have dropped two cannonballs of different masses from the tower to demonstrate that their speed of descent was independent of their mass, in keeping with the scientific law of free fall.

We are in Florence! We have a great little hotel room next to the train station. We walked to the Cattedrale di Santa María del Fiore, or duomo. It was gorgeous! And we had the most delicious panini ever!!

Granted we are in busy part of the city, but so far Florence is way more crowded and busy than NYC and Paris.

all_steps.name: Piazza della Signoria
all_steps.description: Our first stop today was the Piazza della Signoria to see the replica of Michelangelo’s David statue. This is the site of the original statue, but the original has been moved indoors a few blocks away (and tickets are sold out). See Great Art Explained for an explanation on why this statue is so famous: https://youtu.be/-e16DmKH01s?si=68naWfT3rir8QM4m

all_steps.name: Galleria degli Uffizi
all_steps.description:
Harvey got to be our leader today, and he chose to visit Galleria degli Uffizi. The Uffizi Gallery is one of the largest art museums in the world. 

This museum contains thousands of Renaissance works of art, donated to Florence by the Medici family. On display are works of art by Leonardo da Vinci, Botticelli, Cimabue, Michelangelo, Titian, Raphael, Caravaggio, and many more.

all_steps.name: Ponte Vecchio
all_steps.description: Fran was pretty mad here because she dropped her gelato on the ground.

all_steps.name: Museo Galileo
all_steps.description: We next went to the Galileo Museum. It was fun to learn about the great scientific advances during the Renaissance. Fun fact, I share the same birthdate as Galileo!

all_steps.name: Leonardo da Vinci Interactive Museum
all_steps.description:
Leonardo da Vinci was born outside Florence in 1452. He is famous for his magnificent art, including the Mona Lisa and The Last Supper. He was also a brilliant engineer and scientist. He conceived ideas vastly ahead of his own time, conceptually inventing the parachute, the helicopter, an armored fighting vehicle, the use of concentrated solar power, the car and a gun, a rudimentary theory of plate tectonics and the double hull.

We loved playing at this museum!

all_steps.name: Train to Rome
all_steps.description: We are getting really good at this train travel business. Our high speed train Florence to Rome was our most scenic yet! Oh, and Fran (and all of us really) LOVES focaccia!

all_steps.name: Trevi Fountain
all_steps.description:
We are in Rome! We fought the crowds and visited Trevi Fountain.

The Trevi Fountain was built on top of an already existing ancient water source, which was built during the Ancient Roman times in 19BC. The structure was set in a central location, marked at the joint of the three main roads. The name ‘Trevi’ comes from this location, which translates to ‘three-street fountain’. The fountain is famous for its intricate artwork decorated in the Baroque style. Legend states that if your throw one coin into the water, it guarantees your return to Rome. We all threw in a coin!

all_steps.name: Pantheon
all_steps.description:
The first Pantheon was built during the years 27-25 BC. It is the most well-preserved structure from Ancient Rome, having survived floods and earthquakes, and staying relatively untouched for over 2000 years – it is still made up of the original marble and granite from thousands of years ago.

Fun facts – the dome was originally built to be so large that visitors would feel tiny upon entering – which is apparently how one should feel in the presence of Gods. Pantheon translates from Greek to ‘all Gods’. The Pantheon's dome is still the world's largest unreinforced concrete dome. Inside, there are no windows, so it is lit by

all_steps.name: Museum Streets
all_steps.description: It is said that walking the streets of Rome is like walking through a giant outdoor museum. This is so true. We didn’t even go out with these intentions and found so many amazing sites!

all_steps.name: Roma 2nd Ward
all_steps.description:
Today we attended church in the Roma 2nd ward. It was their ward conference, so it was fun to sustain the Prophet and general authorities in Italian. The ward was quite musical! It sounded like an opera during the hymns and the special musical number was a full on string quintet! 

Fran wanted to stay and attend primary. She loved it! Someone helped translate for her during the lesson parts and she said the closing prayer in English.

all_steps.name: Rome Italy Temple
all_steps.description: The Rome temple is gorgeous! We visited the Visitor Center and had a great tour by Sorella Smith from Colorado. The Christus statue with mural and statues of the twelve apostles were breathtaking. There was a stain glass window display (by the same artist as the Paris VC) with symbology of all the Christs parables portrayed. It was a great visit. As Fran said, this and church reset her button :)

all_steps.name: Colosseum
all_steps.description:
The Colosseum was built between 72 A.D and 80 A.D. The Colosseum is the largest amphitheater in the world. This building had 80 entrances and could seat approximately 50,000 spectators who would come to watch sporting events and games. These events included gladiatorial combats, wild animal hunts and, believe it or not, ship naval battles! Most events were free and used by the emperors as a way to gain popularity and support from the public. Below the Colosseum were numerous rooms and underground passages. Here is where the animals and gladiators were kept, waiting to meet their fate in the arena above. There were also 36 trap doors in the arena for special effects! The velarium, an awning that could be pulled over the top of the seating area to provide shade, required skilled shipmen to handle.

It was amazing to see this ancient wonder. The scale of the building was incredible.

all_steps.name: Roman Forum and Palatine Hill
all_steps.description: So many ruins! It was spectacular! It is unbelievable how old and massive these structures are!

all_steps.name: St Peter’s Bascilica
all_steps.description:
Today we visited Vatican City. It is the world’s smallest country by both land area (0.19 sq mi) and population (764 people). Nestled within Rome, the Vatican City became its own country in 1929 and is ruled by the Pope.

Our first stop was St. Peter’s Basilica. This famous and important church is built on Peter, Christ’s apostle, tomb. The dome is the largest dome on earth. The dome is so tall that you could fit the statue of liberty inside it. We climbed the 551 stairs to the top of the dome and were rewarded with magnificent views of Rome and Vatican City. 

Inside the Basilica was stunning with art, mosaics, statues, and other amazing structures. Among them is Michelangelo’s sculpture La Pietà.

all_steps.name: Sistine Chapel
all_steps.description:
*the first three pictures here are from Wikipedia as photography is not allowed in the Sistine Chapel *

Next we visited the Vatican Museum and Sistine Chapel. It took a long time to navigate through the museum with crowds of people. It was hard to appreciate the art that we passed. We spent quite a bit of time in the Sistine Chapel. We were able toto find some seats so Fran could do some art and Harvey and I listened to an audio guide about the chapel.

Fun facts about the Sistine Chapel:
The outside of the chapel is very plan, but the inside walks and ceiling are covered with magnificent frescos painted by Michelangelo and other artists. The ceiling frescoes took Michelangelo four years to complete. In total, they cover 12,000 square feet.  He did not ulay down to paint, but built scaffolding. The art primarily depicts biblical scenes such as the creation and last judgment.

all_steps.name: Via Appia Antica
all_steps.description:
Today we rented bikes and rode the Ancient Appian Way. The Appian Way is a road built in 312 BC, primarily for military reasons. it ran southeast from the Roman Forum to Capua, near Naples, and eventually Brundisium, modern-day Brindisi, in the southern region of Pugli. In its height it covered over 350 miles. Its function and value led to other roads being built, thus “all roads lead to Rome.” It is lined with remains of tombs, catacombs, villas, bath complexes and mausolea.

It was a lovely day to escape crowds and the city. Harvey was totally in his element despite being on a crappy rental mountain bike. I never have seen Fran love biking so much, she totally crushed the bumpy terrain on the e-MTB. We rode about 22km total. It was great!

all_steps.name: Pompei
all_steps.description:
Pompeii was a resort town for the rich and famous Romans. It was built in 6-7th century BC and had approximately 20,000 inhabitants. It was a wealthy town with lots of shops, restaurants, spas, arenas, amphitheaters and houses. It has beautiful frescoes, intricate tile work, and beautiful sculptures. Unknowingly, this town was sitting beneath one of the most deadly volcanoes in the world. Seismic activity was probably common in this area; a large earthquake (5-6 on Richter scale) damaged buildings in 62 AD. 

Then in 79 AD was the great eruption of Mount Vesuvius. The eruption may have lasted about 18 hours. During the first phase is eruption, the volcano vomited hot gas, ash, and pulverized pumice, which caved in roofs in Pompeii and toppled treesh. Although some inhabitants of the city were crushed during this phase, most were able to escape. Next came a series of “pyroclastic surges,” during which turbulent masses of hot ash and lava obliterated any remaining people and structures. Approximately 2,000 died. 

Pompeii was buried and preserved under a 7 meter deep layer of ash and pumice for the next 17 centuries. Archaeological excavations started to take place in the mid-17th century. In 1990s 2/3rds of the city had been excavated. Voids in the ash were left were left by decomposed organic material, these were filled with plaster leaving images of how the victims (men, women, children, dogs, bread, etc) were when the  high-temperature pyroclastic flow hit them.

We took the train to Pompeii and had an archaeological guide show us some of the highlights of the historic city. I was once again amazed at the magnificent cities the Roman’s built such a long time ago.

all_steps.name: Mount Vesuvius
all_steps.description:
We next meet another guide, Mario, where we joined 12 other people on a bus to hike to the caldera of Mount Vesuvius. 

Mount Vesuvius is a stratovolcano that is formed by the collision of the African and Eurasian tectonic plates. It has erupted many times in history, with of course the most notable being in 79 AD. The most notable are 1800 BC, 79 AD, 472, 1631, and lastly in 1944. The many eruptions leading up to 1944 meant that this eruption was not very explosive. We saw the lava fields from that eruption. It is estimated that the next eruption will be very explosive. That, and the fact that 3 million people live at its base in Naples makes this volcano one of the most deadly out there. Its activity is closely monitored, and seems to be sleeping for now. However, on the other side of Naples is the Phlegraean Fields, a large caldera volcano, that is increasingly of concern. Just March of this year there was a large earthquake (4.4 magnitude) and other signs of activity. In response to the rising threat, Italian authorities have an evacuation plan to relocate over a half million people in just 3 days. However, after seeing their city, traffic, and using the public transportation there, I hope it is enough!!

Fun fact- before the 79AD Pompeii eruption, there Mount Somma–Vesuvius volcano was about 2-3km tall. Now there are two peaks, Mount Somma (1,132 m) and Mount Vesuvius (1,281 m).

all_steps.name: Naples
all_steps.description:
Last night in Italy!! 

We spent our last night in Italy at a B&B that we wish we had more time at. The host was so nice! It was on the third floor with no elevator, so she used a winch to pull up Fran’s luggage.

We got napoleon pizza and ate it on our terrace as a storm came in. It was Naples big festival, Festa di San Gennaro, so traffic and crowds were insane. We are glad we made it in and out of that city alive. Driving was crazy!!
